revision.text:
{{Italic title}} {{Infobox game | subject_name=''Villa Paletti'' | image_link= [[Image:Villa1 Paletti.JPG]] | image_caption= | designer=Bill Payne | publisher=Zoch Verlag | players=2–4 | ages=8 and up | setup_time= 5 minutes | playing_time= 30 min | complexity=Medium | strategy=Medium | random_chance=None | skills=[[dexterity|Manual dexterity]] | footnotes= }} '''''Villa Paletti''''' is a [[board game]] of [[game of physical skill|physical skill]] designed by Bill Payne and published in 2001 by [[Zoch Verlag]]. Players compete to build the [[villa]] highest using columns from lower floors without collapsing the structure.
A double-size version of the game, ''Palazzo Paletti'', is also available.
== Gameplay == Each player chooses a colour (in the case of two-player games, each player chooses two colours). They then take their wooden column pieces - three thin, one medium, and one wide - and arrange them on the base mat. The players must then agree on a fair placement of the first "floor", which must lie completely above the base mat and which cannot partially cover any column.
Each player in turn must take one of their columns from any level except the highest, and place it on the highest floor. If they cannot remove one of their columns, they may ask to place the next floor. Each opponent may challenge this decision; if they choose to do so and are successful, they may remove that piece from play, and the player misses their go. If no opponent challenges the player, they may place the next floor on top of the pillars of the current highest floor - again, it must lie completely above the base mat and cannot partially cover any column.
Once a column is placed on the second floor, the player with the most column points (one for thin, two for medium, three for large) on the highest level is the leader. If the tower is collapsed by any other player, the leader has won; if they collapse the tower, the previous leader wins. If the tower collapses before a column is placed on the second floor, or if the first leader collapses the tower, no-one has won.
== Awards == ''Villa Paletti'' won the [[Spiel des Jahres]] 2002, the [[Games 100]] Top dexterity award, the Tric Trac gold medal 2001, Belgian game of the year 2003, finalist in Switzerland, Japan, Finland and more. The [[San Francisco Chronicle]] picked it as their top game for 2004.
== External links == * Zoch Verlag's [https://web.archive.org/web/20080315114859/http://www.zoch-verlag.com/en/games/family-games/villa-paletti.html ''Villa Paletti'' homepage] * {{bgg|2596|''Villa Paletti''|3751|''Palazzo Paletti''}}
{{Spiel des Jahres}}
[[Category:Board games introduced in 2001]] [[Category:Games of physical skill]] [[Category:Spiel des Jahres winners]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Arthur L. Williams Stadium | image = Williams Stadium.JPG | image_size = 300px | nickname = "The Bill" | former names = Willard May Stadium | location = 1972 University Boulevard, [[Lynchburg, Virginia]] 24502 | coordinates = {{Coord|37|21|14.4|N|79|10|30|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = May 8, 1989 | opened = October 21, 1989 | renovated = 2010–2011, 2017–2018 | expanded = 2010, 2018 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Liberty University]] | operator = Liberty University | surface = [[FieldTurf]] | construction_cost = $18 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|18000000|1989}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Haken/Corley and Associates of Raleigh, N.C. | general_contractor= [[Lend Lease Project Management & Construction|McDevitt & Street]]{{cite web|url=http://www.liberty.edu/flames/index.cfm?PID=14874&TeamID=9|publisher=liberty.edu|title=Williams Stadium - Quick Facts|accessdate=September 19, 2015}} | tenants = [[Liberty Flames]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1989–present) | seating_capacity = 25,000 (2018–present)
19,200 (2010–2017)
12,000 (1989–2009) | record_attendance = 50,000+ (2017 Commencement) }} '''Arthur L. Williams Stadium''' is a 25,000 seat football stadium located on the campus of [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia]], USA. The stadium was built in 1989 and plays host to Liberty Flames football, which is a part of the NCAA Division I - Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS). A new field house has recently been constructed at the north end of the stadium. This new facility houses a new home locker room, coaches offices, meeting rooms and training facility as well as a {{convert|16000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} weight room. In the 2009 off season, Liberty University added a video scoreboard on the north end of the field. The video scoreboard measured {{convert|20|ft|m|0}} tall and {{convert|36|ft|m}} wide.{{cite web|url=http://www.liberty.edu/news/index.cfm?PID=18495&MID=9279|publisher=liberty.edu|title=New high-definition scoreboard installed at Williams Stadium|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} This video board was replaced by a massive new high-definition video board in time for the 2018 football season. In September 2011, a ribbon video board was added to the facade of the upper deck. This too was replaced by a state of the art ribbon video board on both the eastern and western facades of the upper deck in 2018. The stadium was named in 1994 to honor [[Arthur L. Williams, Jr.]] who was a major contributor to the University. [[File:Williams Stadium 2.JPG|left|thumb|225px|Williams Stadium after the construction of its new scoreboard]] ==Expansion== Liberty University President Jerry Falwell, Jr. announced on August 28, 2009 a three phase addition to Williams Stadium. The plan was to increase the seating capacity of the stadium from 12,000 seats to 30,000. The first phase of the construction included a five story press box and expanded the stadium by 7,200 seats. This was done by adding a second deck to the home side of the stadium and lengthening the east and west stands of the stadium. The seating capacity was 19,200 after phase one was completed. The estimated cost for the first phase of the project was $18 million. The new press tower was ready for Liberty's Oct. 2, 2010 home game against Savannah State. The tower includes 18 luxury suites, all of which were sold for the 2010 season. Phase two has added a second deck to the student side, which has increased capacity to 25,000, beginning with the 2018 football season. The estimated cost for the second phase of the project was $40 million. Phase three will complete a "horseshoe" around the south end zone, bringing the total capacity to 30,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/williams-stadium-s1804/|publisher=stadiumjourney.com|title=Williams Stadium|accessdate=August 1, 2017}} Williams Stadium has the potential to be expanded past 60,000 in the future. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== [[File:Williams Stadium Field.jpg|thumb|Williams Stadium in 2018]] {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=14874&TeamID=9 Liberty Athletics] * [http://www.liberty.edu/libertyjournal/index.cfm?PID=15758§ion=8&artid=755&CFID=14878447&CFTOKEN=13301942 Major renovations announced for Williams Stadium] {{Liberty Flames football navbox}}{{Liberty University}} {{NCAA Division I FBS independent football venue navbox}} {{Virginia college football venues}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Liberty Flames football]] [[Category:American football venues in Virginia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1989]]

[[File:Korea Special Olympics 14 (8378997198).jpg|thumb|Yongpyong Dome]] '''Yongpyong Dome''' (용평돔) or '''Yongpyong Indoor Ice Rink''' (용평실내빙상경기장) is an [[indoor stadium]] in [[Daegwallyeong-myeon]], [[Pyeongchang]]-gun, [[Gangwon-do (South Korea)|Gangwon-do]], [[South Korea]]. It is part of the complex of [[Yongpyong Resort]]. Completed in 1998, it was constructed by [[Ssangyong]], the then owner of Yongpyong Resort. It was originally built as the main stadium for the [[1999 Asian Winter Games]]. At the games, it was the venue for the opening/closing ceremonies, [[Figure skating at the 1999 Asian Winter Games|figure skating]] and [[Short track speed skating at the 1999 Asian Winter Games|short track speed skating]] events. It was also the main stadium for the [[2013 Special Olympics World Winter Games]]. It is the only indoor stadium in Pyeongchang.
Next to the dome, [[Pyeongchang Olympic Village]], the main [[Olympic Village]] for the [[2018 Winter Olympics]] will be located. The dome will be used as the main dining hall during the Winter Olympics.
